elements.content: Two novel metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized successfully. We adopt a step-by-step assembly strategy, which first synthesize the Cu3 cluster Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz), and then react it with H2BDC under different conditions to form final frameworks. In both MOF structures, the Cu3 clusters are maintained, although certain differences are observed. Compared with HBNU-1, the Cu3 cluster dimerizes into Cu6 cluster in HBNU-2. With this step-by-step cluster assembly strategy, MOF structure predicting becomes possible and may give some reference for MOF structure designing.
elements.clean_text: Two novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized successfully. We adopt a step-by-step assembly strategy, which first synthesize the Cu3 cluster Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz), and then react it with H2BDC under different conditions to form final frameworks. In both MOF structures, the Cu3 clusters are maintained, although certain differences are observed. Compared with HBNU-1, the Cu3 cluster dimerizes into Cu6 cluster in HBNU-2. With this step-by-step cluster assembly strategy, MOF structure predicting becomes possible and may give some reference for MOF structure designing.

elements.content: Two novel metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized with a step-by-step assembly strategy. The Cu3 cluster Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz) is synthesized first, and then we react it with H2BDC under different conditions to form final frameworks. In both MOF structures, the Cu3 clusters are maintained, but somewhat differently, the Cu3 cluster dimerizes into Cu6 cluster in HBNU-2. With this step-by-step cluster assembly strategy, MOF structure predicting becomes possible and may give some reference for MOF structure designing.
elements.clean_text: Two novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized with a step-by-step assembly strategy. The Cu3 cluster Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz) is synthesized first, and then we react it with H2BDC under different conditions to form final frameworks. In both MOF structures, the Cu3 clusters are maintained, but somewhat differently, the Cu3 cluster dimerizes into Cu6 cluster in HBNU-2. With this step-by-step cluster assembly strategy, MOF structure predicting becomes possible and may give some reference for MOF structure designing.

elements.content: During the past decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous organic–inorganic hybrid materials, have attracted much attention of structural scientists all over the world because of their extensive potential applications in the fields of gas adsorption and separation, heterocatalysis, fluorescent sensor, electronic and magnetism, and so on. Great efforts have been devoted to design and synthesize MOFs with multifunctionalities, however, at the most time, the structures of the MOF materials obtained are totally different from our expected results, let alone applying into solving the problems in real life. The diversity nature of connectivities of metal ions, the complexity of inorganic SBUs, and variety of topologies are the main hindrances to MOF structure predicting, leading the application research of MOFs blind more or less.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous organic-inorganic hybrid materials, have attracted much attention of structural scientists all over the world because of their extensive potential applications in the fields of gas adsorption and separation, heterocatalysis, fluorescent sensor, electronic and magnetism, and so on. Great efforts have been devoted to design and synthesize MOFs with multifunctionalities, however, at the most time, the structures of the MOF materials obtained are totally different from our expected results, let alone applying into solving the problems in real life. The diversity nature of connectivities of metal ions, the complexity of inorganic SBUs, and variety of topologies are the main hindrances to MOF structure predicting, leading the application research of MOFs blind more or less.

elements.content: To predict possible structures, scientists have come out three common strategies. The first one, which is also the most common one, is so-called post synthesis modification (PSM). Generally, PSM only introduces target functional groups by in situ reaction or solvent-assisted ligand exchange while the connectivity of the structure keeps unchanged. The second one is named reticular chemistry, which was first proposed by Yaghi and O’Keeffe. A series of isostructural MOFs could be obtained with topology unchanged by ligand extension. The third one is to construct MOF from a specific metal cluster as molecular building block (MBB) or supramolecular building block (SBB) in a step-by-step style. As the MBB/SBB could be predesigned to possess the required geometry, coordination mode and desired directionality, the structure assembled by these MBBs/SBBs with organic linker is decided just by the geometry of linker and topology connection. Eddaoudi et al. have reported a series of rht-MOFs, gea-MOFs, and fcu-MOFs with metal–organic polyhedral as SBBs by bottom-up strategy. Rosi et al. report a series of bio-MOFs constructed by the Zn8(ad)4 as SBB. Hupp et al. have reported a series of ZrMOFs by Zr6O­(OH)4(COO)12 SBB as precursor in a general method. With restricted SBB geometry and coordination mode, structure predicting becomes possible.
elements.clean_text: To predict possible structures, scientists have come out three common strategies. The first one, which is also the most common one, is so-called post synthesis modification (PSM). Generally, PSM only introduces target functional groups by in situ reaction or solvent-assisted ligand exchange while the connectivity of the structure keeps unchanged. The second one is named reticular chemistry, which was first proposed by Yaghi and O'Keeffe. A series of isostructural MOFs could be obtained with topology unchanged by ligand extension. The third one is to construct MOF from a specific metal cluster as molecular building block (MBB) or supramolecular building block (SBB) in a step-by-step style. As the MBB/SBB could be predesigned to possess the required geometry, coordination mode and desired directionality, the structure assembled by these MBBs/SBBs with organic linker is decided just by the geometry of linker and topology connection. Eddaoudi et al. have reported a series of rht-MOFs, gea-MOFs, and fcu-MOFs with metal-organic polyhedral as SBBs by bottom-up strategy. Rosi et al. report a series of bio-MOFs constructed by the Zn8(ad)4 as SBB. Hupp et al. have reported a series of ZrMOFs by Zr6O(OH)4(COO)12 SBB as precursor in a general method. With restricted SBB geometry and coordination mode, structure predicting becomes possible.

elements.content: Herein, we adopt a step-by-step assembly strategy to successfully synthesize two cluster-organic frameworks, HBNU-1 and HBNU-2. First, we synthesize a trinuclear Cu­(II) complex, [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz)] (Cu 3 cluster) (pz = pyrazolate anion) as SBB. Second, the assembly of this Cu3 cluster with terephthalic acid (H2BDC) under solvothermal condition leads to the formation of HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, respectively. However, either no products or products with very low yield could be obtained by directly reacting Hpz, Cu2+, and H2BDC (). In both structures, the Cu3 cluster keeps unchanged. With this step-by-step strategy, possible structure predicting becomes realizable.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we adopt a step-by-step assembly strategy to successfully synthesize two cluster-organic frameworks, HBNU-1 and HBNU-2. First, we synthesize a trinuclear Cu(II) complex, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3(CH3COO)2(Hpz)] (Cu  3  cluster) (pz = pyrazolate anion) as SBB. Second, the assembly of this Cu3 cluster with terephthalic acid (H2BDC) under solvothermal condition leads to the formation of HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, respectively. However, either no products or products with very low yield could be obtained by directly reacting Hpz, Cu2+, and H2BDC (). In both structures, the Cu3 cluster keeps unchanged. With this step-by-step strategy, possible structure predicting becomes realizable.

elements.content: All the reagents were purchased without any purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was conducted by a Rigaku diffractometer (50 kV/20 mA, Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected with a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer. CHN analysis data were collected on a CE-400 (Leeman-labs) analyzer. Gas adsorption experiments were conducted with a Micromeritics ASAP2020 gas adsorption instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the reagents were purchased without any purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was conducted by a Rigaku diffractometer (50 kV/20 mA, Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected with a PerkinElmer thermogravimetric analyzer. CHN analysis data were collected on a CE-400 (Leeman-labs) analyzer. Gas adsorption experiments were conducted with a Micromeritics ASAP2020 gas adsorption instrument.

elements.content: The Cu3 cluster was synthesized according to a reported literature. The synthesis procedure was given as follows: Hpz (0.68 g, 10 mmol) and Cu­(MeCOO)2 (1.5 g, 7.5 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of EtOH. The solution was stirred overnight at room temperature. A blue microcrystalline precipitate was collected after being washed with EtOH three times and air dried.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Cu3 Cluster

The Cu3 cluster was synthesized according to a reported literature. The synthesis procedure was given as follows: Hpz (0.68 g, 10 mmol) and Cu(MeCOO)2 (1.5 g, 7.5 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of EtOH. The solution was stirred overnight at room temperature. A blue microcrystalline precipitate was collected after being washed with EtOH three times and air dried.

elements.content: The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (25 mg, 0.15 mmol), 5 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, large blue crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 35 mg, 60% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-1 = C34H49N10O12Cu3, calculated (%): C, 41.65; H, 5.00; N, 14.29. Found (%): C, 41.01; H, 5.12; N, 14.25.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of HBNU-1 from Cu3 Cluster

The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (25 mg, 0.15 mmol), 5 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, large blue crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 35 mg, 60% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-1 = C34H49N10O12Cu3, calculated (%): C, 41.65; H, 5.00; N, 14.29. Found (%): C, 41.01; H, 5.12; N, 14.25.

elements.content: The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (50 mg, 0.3 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 30 mg, 65% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-2 = C50H61N16O19Cu7, calculated (%): C, 36.73; H, 3.73; N, 13.71. Found (%): C, 35.02; H, 2.15; N, 12.85.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of HBNU-2 from Cu3 Cluster

The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (50 mg, 0.3 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 30 mg, 65% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-2 = C50H61N16O19Cu7, calculated (%): C, 36.73; H, 3.73; N, 13.71. Found (%): C, 35.02; H, 2.15; N, 12.85.

elements.content: Cu­(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 1 mL of DMA, and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, no crystals could be found.
elements.clean_text:
One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-1

Cu(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 1 mL of DMA, and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, no crystals could be found.

elements.content: Cu­(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, few dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 5 mg, 11% based on H2BDC).
elements.clean_text:
One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-2

Cu(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, few dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 5 mg, 11% based on H2BDC).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was measured with a Bruker APEX2 Smart CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å). Data indexing was done by APEX2 software package. Integration was done with SAINT in APEX2 package. Absorption correction was done with SADABS in a multiscan style. Data solvation and refinement were done with SHELXTL-2014 package. Hydrogen atoms were calculated with a riding model.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was measured with a Bruker APEX2 Smart CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å). Data indexing was done by APEX2 software package. Integration was done with SAINT in APEX2 package. Absorption correction was done with SADABS in a multiscan style. Data solvation and refinement were done with SHELXTL-2014 package. Hydrogen atoms were calculated with a riding model.

elements.content: The reaction of Cu­(NO3)2 and pyrazole leads to the formation of the Cu3 cluster according to previous report. PXRD confirmed its purity (Figure S3). Then, the reaction of Cu3 cluster with H2BDC in 85 °C gave the blue block crystal of HBNU-1 formulated as [Cu3(μ3-OH) (pz)3(BDC)1.5(DMF)]·(DMF)2·(HDMA)·(H2O). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that HBNU-1 crystallized in triclinic P1̅ space group with lattice parameter a = 10.6498(4) Å, b = 12.5501(4) Å, c = 16.9471(5) Å, α = 99.125(1)°, β = 97.698(1)°, and γ = 98.722(1)°. The asymmetric unit of HBNU-1 is composed of a trinuclear complex Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3, one and a half BDC molecules, one terminal DMF, two guest DMF molecules, one guest DMA, and one water molecules (a). In the trinuclear Cu3 cluster, Cu1 and Cu2 were four-coordinated and connected to two pyrazoles, one μ3-OH, and one BDC ligand, respectively. However, the Cu3 was five-coordinated and linked to two pyrazoles, one μ3-OH, one BDC ligand, and a terminal DMF. The water molecule interacted with the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in BDC by O–H···O hydrogen bonds (O1W···O3: 2.80 Å, ∠DHA = 162°, O1W···O7: 2.78 Å, ∠DHA = 135°). One guest DMF molecule also interacted with the μ3-OH moiety by O–H···O hydrogen bond (O1···O10: 2.74 Å, ∠DHA = 163°). Interestingly, the guest DMA molecule was protonated and interacted with the water molecule by O–H···O hydrogen bond (O11–H2O···O1W: 1.85 Å, ∠DHA = 167°) (b). Each Cu3 cluster connected to three BDC ligands, forming a 2D honeycomb sheet (c). Each sheet interacted with guest DMF or DMA molecules by hydrogen bonds and then DMF or DMA interacted with another sheet by weak C–H···π interactions between the −CH3 groups and the pz moeities, thus forming a 3D supramolecular structure (d). Adjacent two sheets formed 9 Å × 13 Å cavities, which were filled with four guest DMF molecules (e). The phase purity was confirmed by the similarity between the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns (Figure S4). For further investigating the stability of HBNU-1, PXRD were conducted after the sample was treated under different temperatures and in different solvents, respectively. HBNU-1 could be stable to about 80 °C, and when heated to 100 °C, the crystallinity got very poor, indicating collapse of framework (Figure S5). In addition, HBNU-1 could be stable in common organic solvents such as DMF, DMA, MeOH, EtOH, and MeCN but could not sustain in water (Figure S6). TGA showed that HBNU-1 had a continuous weight loss before 450 °C, indicating the unstability nature of HBNU-1 (Figure S7). The N2 adsorption test was tried but failed as the sample of HBNU-1 was collapsed after activation in vacuum at 50 °C which was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The reaction of Cu(NO3)2 and pyrazole leads to the formation of the Cu3 cluster according to previous report. PXRD confirmed its purity (Figure S3). Then, the reaction of Cu3 cluster with H2BDC in 85 °C gave the blue block crystal of HBNU-1 formulated as [Cu3(μ3-OH) (pz)3(BDC)1.5(DMF)]⋅(DMF)2⋅(HDMA)⋅(H2O). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that HBNU-1 crystallized in triclinic P1̅ space group with lattice parameter a = 10.6498(4) Å, b = 12.5501(4) Å, c = 16.9471(5) Å, α = 99.125(1)°, β = 97.698(1)°, and γ = 98.722(1)°. The asymmetric unit of HBNU-1 is composed of a trinuclear complex Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3, one and a half BDC molecules, one terminal DMF, two guest DMF molecules, one guest DMA, and one water molecules (a). In the trinuclear Cu3 cluster, Cu1 and Cu2 were four-coordinated and connected to two pyrazoles, one μ3-OH, and one BDC ligand, respectively. However, the Cu3 was five-coordinated and linked to two pyrazoles, one μ3-OH, one BDC ligand, and a terminal DMF. The water molecule interacted with the uncoordinated oxygen atoms in BDC by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (O1W⋅⋅⋅O3: 2.80 Å, ∠DHA = 162°, O1W⋅⋅⋅O7: 2.78 Å, ∠DHA = 135°). One guest DMF molecule also interacted with the μ3-OH moiety by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (O1⋅⋅⋅O10: 2.74 Å, ∠DHA = 163°). Interestingly, the guest DMA molecule was protonated and interacted with the water molecule by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (O11-H2O⋅⋅⋅O1W: 1.85 Å, ∠DHA = 167°) (b). Each Cu3 cluster connected to three BDC ligands, forming a 2D honeycomb sheet (c). Each sheet interacted with guest DMF or DMA molecules by hydrogen bonds and then DMF or DMA interacted with another sheet by weak C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the -CH3 groups and the pz moeities, thus forming a 3D supramolecular structure (d). Adjacent two sheets formed 9 Å × 13 Å cavities, which were filled with four guest DMF molecules (e). The phase purity was confirmed by the similarity between the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns (Figure S4). For further investigating the stability of HBNU-1, PXRD were conducted after the sample was treated under different temperatures and in different solvents, respectively. HBNU-1 could be stable to about 80 °C, and when heated to 100 °C, the crystallinity got very poor, indicating collapse of framework (Figure S5). In addition, HBNU-1 could be stable in common organic solvents such as DMF, DMA, MeOH, EtOH, and MeCN but could not sustain in water (Figure S6). TGA showed that HBNU-1 had a continuous weight loss before 450 °C, indicating the unstability nature of HBNU-1 (Figure S7). The N2 adsorption test was tried but failed as the sample of HBNU-1 was collapsed after activation in vacuum at 50 °C which was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S8).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of HBNU-1. (b) Hydrogen bonds in HBNU-1. (c) 2D sheet structure in HBNU-1. (d) 3D structure of HBNU-1. (e) Guest DMF molecules confined in the cavity of HBNU-1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit of HBNU-1. (b) Hydrogen bonds in HBNU-1. (c) 2D sheet structure in HBNU-1. (d) 3D structure of HBNU-1. (e) Guest DMF molecules confined in the cavity of HBNU-1.

elements.content: The reaction of the Cu3 cluster with H2BDC in 100 °C gave the dark red block crystals of HBNU-2 formulated as [Cu3(μ3-O)­(pz)3]­[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3]­[Cu­(BDC)2.5(H2O)]·(DMF)4·(H2O)2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that HBNU-2 crystallized in orthorhombic Cmmm space group with lattice parameter a = 12.94 Å, b = 29.05 Å, and c = 20.34 Å. In the asymmetric unit of HBNU-2, there were three kinds of crystallographic unique Cu atoms in which Cu1 and Cu2 are composed of half a Cu3 cluster and Cu3 is composed of a quarter paddle-wheel structures with a quarter terminal water molecules (a). It was noteworthy that there were three different kinds of Cu clusters in the structure which was relatively rare in reported MOFs till now, namely, Cu3(μ3-O)­(pz)3, Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3, and Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel, respectively. Furthermore, the clusters of Cu3(μ3-O)­(pz)3 and Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3 were connected by three carboxyl groups in BDC ligands, thus dimerizing into a novel Cu6 clusters (b). Each Cu6 cluster is linked to three BDC ligands and each BDC is connected to one Cu6 cluster and one paddle-wheel, thus generating a 2D sheet (c). Each adjacent sheet interacted with each other by μ3-OH···μ3-O hydrogen bonds from the Cu3 cluster moieties, leading to the generation of 3D supramolecular structure (d). There were two kinds of channels in direction [100], namely, rhombic and triangular shapes, whose sizes were 9 and 7 Å measured by Material Studio, respectively (e). Solvent accessible volume was calculated to be as high as 51.4% with PLATON packages. Topology analysis was done by TOPOS 4.0 software package. Each Cu6 cluster is connected to three BDC ligands and interacted with other two Cu6 clusters by hydrogen bonds, so each Cu6 cluster could be simplified as a 5-connected node; and each paddle-wheel could be simplified as a 4-connected node, thus forming a (4,5)-connected mcf-d topology. The point symbol for net was {4·56·63}2{42·62·72}. Phase purity was confirmed by the similarity of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns (Figure S9). For further investigating the stability of HBNU-2, PXRD were conducted after the sample was treated under different temperatures and in different solvents, respectively. HBNU-2 could be stable to about 100 °C (Figure S10). In addition, HBNU-2 could keep its crystallinity in DMF, DMA, and MeOH. However, when immersing in DMSO, HBNU-2 got bad and completely collapsed in water, indicating its poor stability (Figure S11). TGA indicated that HBNU-2 had a 3% weight loss before 200 °C which was mainly attributed to guest molecules in channels. As temperature increased continually, the framework collapsed rapidly (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text: The reaction of the Cu3 cluster with H2BDC in 100 °C gave the dark red block crystals of HBNU-2 formulated as [Cu3(μ3-O)(pz)3][Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3][Cu(BDC)2.5(H2O)]⋅(DMF)4⋅(H2O)2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that HBNU-2 crystallized in orthorhombic Cmmm space group with lattice parameter a = 12.94 Å, b = 29.05 Å, and c = 20.34 Å. In the asymmetric unit of HBNU-2, there were three kinds of crystallographic unique Cu atoms in which Cu1 and Cu2 are composed of half a Cu3 cluster and Cu3 is composed of a quarter paddle-wheel structures with a quarter terminal water molecules (a). It was noteworthy that there were three different kinds of Cu clusters in the structure which was relatively rare in reported MOFs till now, namely, Cu3(μ3-O)(pz)3, Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3, and Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel, respectively. Furthermore, the clusters of Cu3(μ3-O)(pz)3 and Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3 were connected by three carboxyl groups in BDC ligands, thus dimerizing into a novel Cu6 clusters (b). Each Cu6 cluster is linked to three BDC ligands and each BDC is connected to one Cu6 cluster and one paddle-wheel, thus generating a 2D sheet (c). Each adjacent sheet interacted with each other by μ3-OH⋅⋅⋅μ3-O hydrogen bonds from the Cu3 cluster moieties, leading to the generation of 3D supramolecular structure (d). There were two kinds of channels in direction [100], namely, rhombic and triangular shapes, whose sizes were 9 and 7 Å measured by Material Studio, respectively (e). Solvent accessible volume was calculated to be as high as 51.4% with PLATON packages. Topology analysis was done by TOPOS 4.0 software package. Each Cu6 cluster is connected to three BDC ligands and interacted with other two Cu6 clusters by hydrogen bonds, so each Cu6 cluster could be simplified as a 5-connected node; and each paddle-wheel could be simplified as a 4-connected node, thus forming a (4,5)-connected mcf-d topology. The point symbol for net was {4⋅56⋅63}2{42⋅62⋅72}. Phase purity was confirmed by the similarity of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns (Figure S9). For further investigating the stability of HBNU-2, PXRD were conducted after the sample was treated under different temperatures and in different solvents, respectively. HBNU-2 could be stable to about 100 °C (Figure S10). In addition, HBNU-2 could keep its crystallinity in DMF, DMA, and MeOH. However, when immersing in DMSO, HBNU-2 got bad and completely collapsed in water, indicating its poor stability (Figure S11). TGA indicated that HBNU-2 had a 3% weight loss before 200 °C which was mainly attributed to guest molecules in channels. As temperature increased continually, the framework collapsed rapidly (Figure S12).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of HBNU-2. (b) Structure of Cu6 cluster. (c) 2D sheet in HBNU-2. (d) Hydrogen bonds between adjacent sheets. (e) 3D structure of HBNU-2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Asymmetric unit of HBNU-2. (b) Structure of Cu6 cluster. (c) 2D sheet in HBNU-2. (d) Hydrogen bonds between adjacent sheets. (e) 3D structure of HBNU-2.

elements.content: To assess the porosity of HBNU-2, the sample activation was done before N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was soaked in MeOH for 2 days and then in CH2Cl2 for other 2 days before treating in 80 °C for 8 h. N2 sorption isotherm showed a typical type-I adsorption curve, indicating the microporosity nature of HBNU-2. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area was calculated to be about 488 m2 g–1 with the pore volume 0.808 cm3 g–1. Pore size distribution was calculated according to the nonlocal density functional theory, which showed two narrow pore width distribution located at 6.1 and 8.5 Å, well agreed with that measured by material studio mentioned above ().
elements.clean_text: To assess the porosity of HBNU-2, the sample activation was done before N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was soaked in MeOH for 2 days and then in CH2Cl2 for other 2 days before treating in 80 °C for 8 h. N2 sorption isotherm showed a typical type-I adsorption curve, indicating the microporosity nature of HBNU-2. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area was calculated to be about 488 m2 g-1 with the pore volume 0.808 cm3 g-1. Pore size distribution was calculated according to the nonlocal density functional theory, which showed two narrow pore width distribution located at 6.1 and 8.5 Å, well agreed with that measured by material studio mentioned above ().

elements.content: N2 adsorption isotherm of HBNU-2 at 77 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 adsorption isotherm of HBNU-2 at 77 K.

elements.content: To evaluate the sorption performance of HBNU-2, N2 and CO2 adsorption experiments were conducted. The maximum adsorption amounts of CO2 were 48.68 and 35.30 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively; and the results of N2 were 13.97 and 4.21 cm3 g–1, respectively (a). For further investigation of CO2/N2 separation performance of HBNU-2, ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method was used. The dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation was adopted for nonlinear curve fitting the experimental data (Figure S13). The selectivities for CO2/N2 were 11.73 and 9.33 at 273 and 298 K under 101 kPa, respectively (b). This relatively low adsorption capacity of CO2 and CO2/N2 selectivity than many MOFs (Table S1) was mainly attributed to the nonunsaturated metal sites in the Cu6 clusters.

The maximum adsorption amounts of CO2 were 48.68 and 35.30 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively; and the results of N2 were 13.97 and 4.21 cm3 g-1, respectively (a). For further investigation of CO2/N2 separation performance of HBNU-2, ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method was used. The dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation was adopted for nonlinear curve fitting the experimental data (Figure S13). The selectivities for CO2/N2 were 11.73 and 9.33 at 273 and 298 K under 101 kPa, respectively (b). This relatively low adsorption capacity of CO2 and CO2/N2 selectivity than many MOFs (Table S1) was mainly attributed to the nonunsaturated metal sites in the Cu6 clusters.

elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Adsorption isotherms of HBNU-2. (b) IAST CO2/N2 adsorption selectivity at 273 and 298 K.

elements.content: Two novel MOFs, HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized with a step-by-step cluster assembly strategy from Cu3(μ3-OH)­(pz)3 cluster successfully. With the structure of Cu3 clusters maintained, the final framework structure predicting becomes possible, although the dimerization of Cu3 cluster in HBNU-2 is out of our expectation. Further investigation is focused on screening rigid and inert clusters for MOF construction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two novel MOFs, HBNU-1 and HBNU-2, have been synthesized with a step-by-step cluster assembly strategy from Cu3(μ3-OH)(pz)3 cluster successfully. With the structure of Cu3 clusters maintained, the final framework structure predicting becomes possible, although the dimerization of Cu3 cluster in HBNU-2 is out of our expectation. Further investigation is focused on screening rigid and inert clusters for MOF construction.

cln_elements.content:
The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (25 mg, 0.15 mmol), 5 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, large blue crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 35 mg, 60% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-1 = C34H49N10O12Cu3, calculated (%): C, 41.65; H, 5.00; N, 14.29. Found (%): C, 41.01; H, 5.12; N, 14.25.

Synthesis of HBNU-2 from Cu<sub>3</sub> Cluster

The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (50 mg, 0.3 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 30 mg, 65% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-2 = C50H61N16O19Cu7, calculated (%): C, 36.73; H, 3.73; N, 13.71. Found (%): C, 35.02; H, 2.15; N, 12.85.

One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-1

Cu­(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 1 mL of DMA, and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, no crystals could be found.

One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-2

Cu­(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, few dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 5 mg, 11% based on H2BDC).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of HBNU-1 from Cu3 Cluster

The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (25 mg, 0.15 mmol), 5 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1 mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, large blue crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 35 mg, 60% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-1 = C34H49N10O12Cu3, calculated (%): C, 41.65; H, 5.00; N, 14.29. Found (%): C, 41.01; H, 5.12; N, 14.25.

Synthesis of HBNU-2 from Cu3 Cluster

The Cu3 cluster (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (50 mg, 0.3 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 30 mg, 65% based on Cu3 cluster). Elemental analysis for HBNU-2 = C50H61N16O19Cu7, calculated (%): C, 36.73; H, 3.73; N, 13.71. Found (%): C, 35.02; H, 2.15; N, 12.85.

One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-1

Cu(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (8.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 1 mL of DMA, and 0.5 mL of water were mixed in a 20 mL glass vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in an 85 °C oven for about 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, no crystals could be found.

One-Pot Solvothermal Synthesis of HBNU-2

Cu(NO3)2 (18.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2BDC (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hpz (6.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), 5 mL of DMF, 0.5 mL of water, and 0.5 mL of EtOH were mixed in a 20 mL vial. The mixture was stirred till the solution got clear and then heated in a 100 °C oven for about 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, few dark red crystals were collected and then washed with DMF and air dried (yield: 5 mg, 11% based on H2BDC).

cln_elements.content:
To assess the porosity of HBNU-2, the sample activation was done before N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was soaked in MeOH for 2 days and then in CH2Cl2 for other 2 days before treating in 80 °C for 8 h. N2 sorption isotherm showed a typical type-I adsorption curve, indicating the microporosity nature of HBNU-2. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area was calculated to be about 488 m2 g–1 with the pore volume 0.808 cm3 g–1. Pore size distribution was calculated according to the nonlocal density functional theory, which showed two narrow pore width distribution located at 6.1 and 8.5 Å, well agreed with that measured by material studio mentioned above ().

To evaluate the sorption performance of HBNU-2, N2 and CO2 adsorption experiments were conducted. The maximum adsorption amounts of CO2 were 48.68 and 35.30 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively; and the results of N2 were 13.97 and 4.21 cm3 g–1, respectively (a). For further investigation of CO2/N2 separation performance of HBNU-2, ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method was used. The dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation was adopted for nonlinear curve fitting the experimental data (Figure S13). The selectivities for CO2/N2 were 11.73 and 9.33 at 273 and 298 K under 101 kPa, respectively (b). This relatively low adsorption capacity of CO2 and CO2/N2 selectivity than many MOFs (Table S1) was mainly attributed to the nonunsaturated metal sites in the Cu6 clusters.
cln_elements.clean_text:
To assess the porosity of HBNU-2, the sample activation was done before N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K. The sample was soaked in MeOH for 2 days and then in CH2Cl2 for other 2 days before treating in 80 °C for 8 h. N2 sorption isotherm showed a typical type-I adsorption curve, indicating the microporosity nature of HBNU-2. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area was calculated to be about 488 m2 g-1 with the pore volume 0.808 cm3 g-1. Pore size distribution was calculated according to the nonlocal density functional theory, which showed two narrow pore width distribution located at 6.1 and 8.5 Å, well agreed with that measured by material studio mentioned above ().

To evaluate the sorption performance of HBNU-2, N2 and CO2 adsorption experiments were conducted. The maximum adsorption amounts of CO2 were 48.68 and 35.30 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively; and the results of N2 were 13.97 and 4.21 cm3 g-1, respectively (a). For further investigation of CO2/N2 separation performance of HBNU-2, ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) method was used. The dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation was adopted for nonlinear curve fitting the experimental data (Figure S13). The selectivities for CO2/N2 were 11.73 and 9.33 at 273 and 298 K under 101 kPa, respectively (b). This relatively low adsorption capacity of CO2 and CO2/N2 selectivity than many MOFs (Table S1) was mainly attributed to the nonunsaturated metal sites in the Cu6 clusters.

<caption>
<title>Step-by-Step Assemble Strategy</title>
</caption>

metadata.title:
Step-by-Step Assembly of Metal–Organic
Frameworks from Trinuclear Cu3 Clusters
